[[S:KRATOS:vo_glo_brok_interrupt_bark_030_kra:17-1234]]
Atreus, come.
*121329*
[[S:SON:vo_glo_brok_interrupt_bark_040_son:54-642]]
Next time…
*121330*
[[S:KRATOS:vo_glo_brok_interrupt_bark_050_kra:0-900]]
We must go!
*121331*
[[S:SON:vo_glo_brok_interrupt_bark_060_son:0-1370]]
Sorry, you heard him…
*121332*
[[S:KRATOS:vo_glo_brok_interrupt_bark_070_kra:33-524]]
Enough!
*121333*
[[S:SON:vo_glo_brok_interrupt_bark_080_son:57-891]]
We’ll catch up later…
*121334*
[[S:KRATOS:vo_glo_brok_interrupt_bark_090_kra:46-610]]
Now.
*121335*
[[S:SON:vo_glo_brok_interrupt_bark_100_son:0-540]]
See you.
*121336*
[[S:SINDRI:vo_glo_brok_one_shop_010_sin:40-1250]]
Something else we can do for you?
*121337*
[[S:SON:vo_glo_brok_one_shop_020_son:50-770]]
Nah, just…
*121338*
[[S:::1460-2500]]
glad you guys worked it out.
*121339*
[[S:SINDRI:vo_glo_brok_one_shop_030_sin:0-1630]]
Ah. Well…
*121340*
[[S:::2460-3750]]
I could say the same to you.
*121341*
[[S:BROK:vo_glo_brok_one_shop_040_brk:77-577]]
Ha!
*121342*
[[S:SON:vo_glo_brok_one_shop_050_son:20-1950]]
I guess I was getting a bit full of myself.
*121343*
[[S:BROK:vo_glo_brok_one_shop_060_brk:90-2750]]
Told him what he needed to hear, how’s it sounds to me.
*121344*
[[S:SON:vo_glo_brok_one_shop_070_son:0-1000]]
Just the same…
*121345*
[[S:::2190-3800]]
I’m sorry for how I spoke to you, Sindri.
*121346*
[[S:::5170-5981]]
You forgive me?
*121347*
[[S:SINDRI:vo_glo_brok_one_shop_080_sin:30-950]]
Already have.
*121348*
[[S:::1860-3930]]
Like you said, it all worked out.
*121349*
[[S:::4580-5080]]
Now
*121350*
[[S:::5760-7510]]
let us get back to work before I get…
*121351*
[[S:::8930-9680]]
sentimental…
*121352*
[[S:BROK:vo_glo_brok_fimbulscrote_010_brk:110-3960]]
I’m telling you, it’s Fimbulwinter. I can feel it in my scrote—
*121353*
[[S:::4570-5860]]
this is the big one!
*121354*
[[S:SINDRI:vo_glo_brok_fimbulscrote_020_sin:480-1520]]
Stop saying that.
*121355*
[[S:::2180-3550]]
Oh, you’re making me very nervous.
*121356*
[[S:::3950-5670]]
It was bound to snow sooner or later.
*121357*
[[S:BROK:vo_glo_brok_fimbulscrote_030_brk:50-1980]]
That ain’t just snow, and you know it!
*121358*
[[S:::2640-4000]]
It’s the end times.
*121359*
[[S:SINDRI:vo_glo_brok_fimbulscrote_040_sin:40-2250]]
How dare you make me the voice of reason!
*121360*
[[S:SON:vo_glo_brok_fimbulscrote_050_son:50-550]]
Guys?
*121361*
[[S:SINDRI:vo_glo_brok_fimbulscrote_060_sin:0-1190]]
Just discussing the weather.
*121362*
[[S:::1800-3250]]
Bit of a cold snap lately.
*121363*
[[S:BROK:vo_glo_brok_fimbulscrote_070_brk:60-3776]]
What he means is, Fimbulwinter’s upon us, boys!
*121364*
[[S:::3947-6182]]
The winter to end all winters!
*121365*
[[S:::6290-8106]]
I can feel it in my scrote!
*121366*
[[S:SON:vo_glo_brok_fimbulscrote_080_son:240-1850]]
Yeah, we…
*121367*
[[S:::2370-3177]]
we heard.
*121368*
[[S:SINDRI:vo_glo_brok_fimbulscrote_090_sin:0-1230]]
So, if you’re heading home…
*121369*
[[S:::1600-4500]]
try to keep moving, and, also, to not die.
*121370*
[[S:BROK:vo_glo_brok_fimbulscrote_100_brk:60-1830]]
Or if you’re not heading home…
*121371*
[[S:::2290-3348]]
same advice.
*121372*
[[S:SINDRI:vo_glo_brok_huldra_faye_010_sin:0-1500]]
So how was your trip to Jötunheim?
*121373*
[[S:BROK:vo_glo_brok_huldra_faye_020_brk:60-2114]]
Will you give them a little privacy?
*121374*
[[S:::2269-4204]]
The kid just found out he’s a Giant,
*121375*
[[S:::4353-6660]]
he doesn’t need you interrogating him!
*121376*
[[S:SON:vo_glo_brok_huldra_faye_030_son:0-1390]]
Brok! You knew?
*121377*
[[S:SINDRI:vo_glo_brok_huldra_faye_040_sin:430-4265]]
Oh, we knew Faye was the last Guardian of the Jötnar left in Midgard.
*121378*
[[S:::4494-5880]]
That’s why we made her the axe.
*121379*
[[S:::6430-8500]]
We hoped it could restore the balance of power—
*121380*
[[S:BROK:vo_glo_brok_huldra_faye_050_brk:260-3250]]
After Thor went all BRE-zerk with our hammer!
*121381*
[[S:SINDRI:vo_glo_brok_huldra_faye_060_sin:110-1460]]
—though in the end, it seems,
*121382*
[[S:::1980-3320]]
she chose another path.
*121383*
[[S:::3720-5840]]
She chose, well… you.
*121384*
[[S:::6860-7860]]
Both of you.
*121385*
[[S:::9180-12685]]
I suppose she figured that was the best chance for the Giants to live on.
*121386*
[[S:::12802-14777]]
And now I suppose
*121387*
[[S:::15460-16500]]
that’s up to you.
*121388*
[[S:MIMIR:vo_glo_brok_huldra_faye_070_mmr:0-2780]]
How about that. A young Jötunn with us the whole time…
*121389*
[[S:::3450-7933]]
and the son of Laufey the Just! I should have seen it before…
*121390*
[[S:BROK:vo_glo_brok_gen_weapon_010_brk:0-1349]]
Good n’ deadly!
*121391*
[[S:BROK:vo_glo_brok_gen_weapon_020_brk:0-2250]]
You take care o’ this, it’ll take care o’you.
*121392*
[[S:BROK:vo_glo_brok_gen_weapon_030_brk:120-1160]]
That right there…
*121393*
[[S:::1540-3000]]
that’s quality.
*121394*
[[S:SON:vo_glo_muspelbrok_010_son:0-1250]]
You must like the heat, Brok…
*121395*
[[S:BROK:vo_glo_muspelbrok_020_brk:0-2380]]
Heat’s damned useful in my line o’ work.
*121396*
[[S:::2770-5360]]
Even makes space itself more pliable.
*121397*
[[S:::5870-8187]]
Take those magic doors you love so much
*121398*
[[S:::8379-12622]]
—’round here they all go right to one another, no proddin’ from ol’ Brok.
*121399*
[[S:::13020-18100]]
Go up yonder and wake some up, you’ll see—gettin’ around Muspel’s a cinch…
*121400*
[[S:::18447-20200]]
Long as you don’t end up cooked.
*121401*
[[S:KRATOS:vo_glo_peak_brok_010_kra:0-2750]]
You had a way around the black breath all along?
*121402*
[[S:BROK:vo_glo_peak_brok_020_brk:19-3847]]
Now don’t go thinkin’ I coulda gotten you past it, you big sack o’ meat.
*121403*
[[S:::4195-7604]]
I got ways around most everything, especially up here.
*121404*
[[S:::8329-11079]]
Time was, my folk had the run o’ this joint.
*121405*
[[S:::11494-15407]]
Improved the design of the Jötnar traps and built work-arounds ta boot.
*121406*
[[S:::15953-21271]]
Why ya think they’re so devious? Oh, that reminds me—watch out for traps.
*121407*
[[S:BROK:vo_glo_still_quiet_010_brk:0-4050]]
Say, what’s with you two? All clammed up and scowlin’…
*121408*
[[S:::4342-6940]]
it’s like you finally noticed everything smells like shit.
*121409*
[[S:MIMIR:vo_glo_still_quiet_020_mmr:21-3646]]
Oh, don’t worry, I’m sure they’ll be back to yelling at each other momentarily.
*121410*
[[S:SON:vo_glo_boatlore_aesop_on_010_son:0-500]]
SO!
*121411*
[[S:::1250-2750]]
Know any good stories to pass the time?
*121412*
[[S:KRATOS:vo_glo_boatlore_aesop_on_020_kra:0-1000]]
What kind of story?
*121413*
[[S:SON:vo_glo_boatlore_aesop_on_030_son:22-855]]
I don’t know…
*121414*
[[S:::1959-3390]]
Mother always had stories.
*121415*
[[S:::4297-5825]]
Weren’t you told any when you were a boy?
*121416*
[[S:SON:vo_glo_boatlore_aesop_resume01_010_son:80-2400]]
So could you think of any stories to tell?
*121417*
[[S:SON:vo_glo_boatlore_aesop_resume02_010_son:50-1500]]
So what story were you going to tell?
*121418*
[[S:SON:vo_glo_boatlore_aesop_resume03_010_son:80-650]]
So
*121419*
[[S:::1310-2750]]
what happened with the hare and the tortoise?
*121420*
[[S:KRATOS:vo_glo_boatlore_aesop_secbrk01_010_kra:60-2140]]
There was a man I knew of long ago.
*121421*
[[S:::3110-4350]]
His stories were brief,
*121422*
[[S:::4850-5500]]
and purposeful.
*121423*
[[S:SON:vo_glo_boatlore_aesop_secbrk01_020_son:70-1130]]
Sounds…
*121424*
[[S:::1630-2240]]
fun?
*121425*
[[S:::3450-4250]]
Do you remember any?
*121426*
[[S:KRATOS:vo_glo_boatlore_aesop_secbrk02_010_kra:29-3872]]
Hm… there was one that concerned a hare and a tortoise.
*121428*
[[S:SON:vo_glo_boatlore_aesop_secbrk02_020_son:33-1030]]
Like the Witch’s house?
*121429*
[[S:KRATOS:vo_glo_boatlore_aesop_secbrk02_030_kra:41-914]]
Unlikely.
*121430*
[[S:SON:vo_glo_boatlore_aesop_secbrk02_040_son:0-910]]
So what happens?
*121431*
[[S:KRATOS:vo_glo_boatlore_aesop_secbrk03_010_kra:40-1920]]
They wager on a race between them.
*121432*
[[S:KRATOS:vo_glo_boatlore_aesop_secbrk03_020_kra:20-3060]]
The hare is too confident of victory, and foolish,
*121433*
[[S:::3490-5750]]
while the tortoise is steady, and disciplined.
*121434*
[[S:KRATOS:vo_glo_boatlore_aesop_secbrk03_030_kra:37-1191]]
The tortoise wins.
*121435*
[[S:SON:vo_glo_boatlore_aesop_secbrk03_040_son:29-3058]]
You… haven’t told a lot of stories, have you.
*121436*
[[S:SON:vo_glo_boatlore_scorpion_resume01_010_son:0-2430]]
So you were saying a scorpion wanted to cross a river…
*121437*
[[S:KRATOS:vo_glo_boatlore_scorpion_resume01_020_kra:0-650]]
Yes…
*121438*
[[S:SON:vo_glo_boatlore_scorpion_resume02_010_son:0-1940]]
So did the frog give a ride to the scorpion?
*121439*
[[S:SON:vo_glo_boatlore_scorpion_resume03_010_son:20-2000]]
So the scorpion really stung the frog?
*121440*
[[S:KRATOS:vo_glo_boatlore_scorpion_resume03_020_kra:30-715]]
Yes…
*121441*
[[S:SON:vo_glo_boatlore_scorpion_resume04_010_son:40-1460]]
What you said about the scorpion…
*121442*
[[S:::2430-4270]]
that it couldn’t escape his nature to do harm…
*121443*
[[S:KRATOS:vo_glo_boatlore_scorpion_secbrk00_010_kra:0-3500]]
There was once a scorpion who wished to travel to the other side of a river.
*121444*
[[S:SON:vo_glo_boatlore_scorpion_secbrk01_010_son:0-500]]
Why?
*121445*
[[S:KRATOS:vo_glo_boatlore_scorpion_secbrk01_020_kra:220-2500]]
If you continue to interrupt, I will end the story.
*121446*
[[S:SON:vo_glo_boatlore_scorpion_secbrk01_030_son:40-750]]
Okay, okay.
*121447*
[[S:KRATOS:vo_glo_boatlore_scorpion_secbrk02_010_kra:70-2000]]
The scorpion asked a frog for help.
*121448*
[[S:KRATOS:vo_glo_boatlore_scorpion_secbrk03_010_kra:50-5000]]
He told the frog that if he gave him a ride across the river on his back, he would be rewarded.
*121449*
[[S:KRATOS:vo_glo_boatlore_scorpion_secbrk04_010_kra:50-3130]]
The frog protested, fearing the scorpion would sting him.
*121450*
[[S:KRATOS:vo_glo_boatlore_scorpion_secbrk05_010_kra:20-4500]]
The scorpion assured the frog that he would not sting him or they would both drown in the river.
*121451*
[[S:KRATOS:vo_glo_boatlore_scorpion_secbrk06_010_kra:0-1090]]
The frog agreed,
*121452*
[[S:::1480-4460]]
but halfway across the river, the scorpion stung him.
*121453*
[[S:KRATOS:vo_glo_boatlore_scorpion_secbrk07_010_kra:20-5000]]
The frog was mortally wounded and they both sunk to the bottom of the river and perished.
*121454*
[[S:SON:vo_glo_boatlore_scorpion_secbrk08_010_son:43-2834]]
That’s sad. Why would the scorpion do that?
*121455*
[[S:KRATOS:vo_glo_boatlore_scorpion_secbrk09_010_kra:0-940]]
He was a scorpion.
*121456*
[[S:::1510-3000]]
It is his nature to do harm.
*121457*
[[S:SON:vo_glo_boatlore_scorpion_secbrk09_020_son:38-502]]
Oh….
*121458*
[[S:SON:vo_glo_boatlore_scorpion_secbrk10_010_son:41-2113]]
That’s just what mom used to say about the gods.
*121459*
[[S:KRATOS:vo_glo_boatlore_scorpion_secbrk11_010_kra:0-2000]]
Your mother always spoke the truth.
*121460*
[[S:KRATOS:vo_glo_boatlore_scorpion_secbrk11_020_kra:1380-2250]]
Enough stories.
*121461*
[[S:SON:vo_glo_boatlore_in_war_resume01_010_son:0-620]]
So…
*121462*
[[S:::1110-2900]]
what do you mean, I see with the eyes of a child?
*121463*
[[S:SON:vo_glo_boatlore_in_war_resume02_010_son:20-1500]]
What else were you going to tell me about war?
*121464*
[[S:SON:vo_glo_boatlore_in_war_secbrk00_010_son:21-1800]]
It’s sad the Elves can’t work things out.
*121465*
[[S:SON:vo_glo_boatlore_in_war_secbrk01_010_son:0-1970]]
Alfheim’s such a beautiful place, but…
*121466*
[[S:::2710-3500]]
war makes it ugly.
*121467*
[[S:KRATOS:vo_glo_boatlore_in_war_secbrk02_010_kra:90-1750]]
You see with the eyes of a child.
*121468*
[[S:KRATOS:vo_glo_boatlore_in_war_secbrk03_010_kra:0-3250]]
In war, a soldier sees beauty only in the blood of his enemy.
*121469*
[[S:KRATOS:vo_glo_boatlore_in_war_secbrk04_010_kra:0-1440]]
The rest of him is lost—
*121470*
[[S:::2040-3500]]
sometimes never to return.
*121471*
[[S:SON:vo_glo_boatlore_in_war_secbrk05_010_son:40-660]]
You…
*121472*
[[S:::1470-2530]]
know about war,
*121473*
[[S:::3260-3780]]
don’t you…
*121474*
[[S:KRATOS:vo_glo_boatlore_in_war_secbrk06_010_kra:0-3750]]
Wars are fought for two things… survival, or advantage.
*121475*
[[S:KRATOS:vo_glo_boatlore_in_war_secbrk07_010_kra:0-2210]]
Battles may be won by the better soldier.
*121476*
[[S:KRATOS:vo_glo_boatlore_in_war_secbrk08_010_kra:40-4750]]
Wars are won by those who are willing to sacrifice everything to ensure victory.
*121477*
[[S:SON:vo_glo_boatlore_moms_war_resume01_010_son:60-620]]
So…
*121478*
[[S:::1390-3000]]
what were you telling me about mom’s war?
*121479*
[[S:SON:vo_glo_boatlore_moms_war_resume02_010_son:20-630]]
So…
*121480*
[[S:::1180-3750]]
Brok and Sindri made mom the axe just to help her survive?
*121481*
[[S:SON:vo_glo_boatlore_moms_war_resume03_010_son:0-430]]
So…
*121482*
[[S:::1110-2690]]
what were you telling me about mom’s war?
*121483*
[[S:SON:vo_glo_boatlore_moms_war_secbrk00_010_son:210-910]]
Sindri said…
*121484*
[[S:::1500-2650]]
mother was a warrior.
*121485*
[[S:SON:vo_glo_boatlore_moms_war_secbrk01_010_son:40-1000]]
Was she in a war too?
*121486*
[[S:KRATOS:vo_glo_boatlore_moms_war_secbrk02_010_kra:0-750]]
Of a sort.
*121487*
[[S:KRATOS:vo_glo_boatlore_moms_war_secbrk03_010_kra:0-4000]]
Her family was decimated by hostile rivals, and she alone survived.
*121488*
[[S:KRATOS:vo_glo_boatlore_moms_war_secbrk04_010_kra:0-1550]]
She walked the warrior’s path,
*121489*
[[S:::1980-3550]]
but her war was to live on.
*121490*
[[S:::4250-6500]]
To brave an unforgiving world alone.
*121491*
[[S:SON:vo_glo_boatlore_moms_war_secbrk05_010_son:40-2430]]
And that’s why she asked Sindri and Brok to make her the Axe?
*121492*
[[S:KRATOS:vo_glo_boatlore_moms_war_secbrk06_010_kra:0-4250]]
She had the strength to wield such a weapon, and the wisdom to use it for good.
*121493*
[[S:KRATOS:vo_glo_boatlore_moms_war_secbrk07_010_kra:0-2250]]
She found purpose in protecting the weak.
*121494*
[[S:SON:vo_glo_boatlore_moms_war_secbrk08_010_son:0-560]]
So…
*121495*
[[S:::1070-2000]]
she’d help out the Elves?
*121496*
[[S:KRATOS:vo_glo_boatlore_moms_war_secbrk09_020_kra:30-650]]
No.
*121497*
[[S:SON:vo_glo_boatlore_ocean_resume01_010_son:30-560]]
So…
*121498*
[[S:::1890-4150]]
what happened to the sailors who drank too much seawater?
*121499*
[[S:SON:vo_glo_boatlore_ocean_resume02_010_son:250-940]]
So…
*121500*
[[S:::1490-3250]]
the sailors who heard voices at sea…
*121501*
[[S:::4220-5000]]
how did you fix them?
*121502*
[[S:SON:vo_glo_boatlore_ocean_secbrk00_010_son:0-560]]
Father?
*121503*
[[S:::1370-3000]]
You ever know anyone else who heard voices?
*121504*
[[S:KRATOS:vo_glo_boatlore_ocean_secbrk01_010_kra:0-2000]]
I knew desperate men at sea who,
*121505*
[[S:::2440-6720]]
when our supplies ran dry, would quench their thirst by drinking seawater.
*121506*
[[S:KRATOS:vo_glo_boatlore_ocean_secbrk02_010_kra:0-1660]]
They swore the sirens—
*121507*
[[S:::2070-4873]]
evil creatures singing to them from nearby islands—
*121508*
[[S:::5065-8283]]
were in fact their wives and daughters, calling them home.
*121509*
[[S:KRATOS:vo_glo_boatlore_ocean_secbrk03_010_kra:40-3250]]
They endangered the crew, steering us toward the reefs.
*121510*
[[S:SON:vo_glo_boatlore_ocean_secbrk04_010_son:60-570]]
Um…
*121511*
[[S:::1100-2000]]
How did you fix them?
*121512*
[[S:KRATOS:vo_glo_boatlore_ocean_secbrk05_010_kra:40-1380]]
We threw them overboard.
*121513*
[[S:SON:vo_glo_boatlore_ocean_secbrk06_010_son:40-868]]
Oh.
*121514*
[[S:::2130-5228]]
Well, good thing I didn’t drink any seawater,
*121515*
[[S:::6447-6900]]
right…?
*121516*
[[S:KRATOS:vo_glo_boatlore_ocean_secbrk06_020_kra:12-939]]
Yes it is.
*121517*
[[S:SON:vo_glo_boatlore_aesop_intro_010_son:0-1230]]
Do we have time for another story?
*121518*
[[S:KRATOS:vo_glo_boatlore_aesop_intro_020_kra:147-685]]
Hm.
*121519*
[[S:::1510-2171]]
A short one.
*121520*
[[S:SON:vo_glo_boatlore_aesop_intro_030_son:9-1104]]
How about one more story?

*121736*

*121773*

*121780*

*121789*

*121794*

mostly.

[[S:::2860-4430]]

*121852*
[[S:::4920-5500]]
mostly.

If you remember,
*121861*

*121875*

*122231*
[[S:MIMIR:vo_glo_boatlore_OdnLore3_secbrk06_010_mmr:0-4250]]
Odin’s wrath was fierce, and his curses upon her were more than she’d dared to fear.
*122232*
[[S:SON:vo_glo_boatlore_OdnLore3_secbrk07_010_son:26-1809]]
But her magic was so much stronger than his…
*122233*
[[S:MIMIR:vo_glo_boatlore_OdnLore3_secbrk08_010_mmr:40-2978]]
After so much time together, he knew her vulnerabilities,
*122234*
[[S:::3221-6250]]
and exploited them to craft curses she could never break.
*122235*
[[S:SON:vo_glo_boatlore_OdnLore3_secbrk09_010_son:160-780]]
Oh…
*122236*
[[S:::1260-2820]]
like not being able to leave Midgard.
*122237*
[[S:MIMIR:vo_glo_boatlore_OdnLore3_secbrk10_010_mmr:40-2492]]
Worse still, he robbed her of her warrior spirit.
*122238*
[[S:::2919-6061]]
Freya cannot fight—even to defend herself.
*122239*
[[S:::6364-10254]]
No living thing may she harm, by blade nor spell.
*122240*
[[S:::10690-14613]]
In a world this belligerent, what choice does she have but isolation?
*122241*
[[S:MIMIR:vo_glo_boatlore_OdnLore3_secbrk10_010_mmr_d:180-4000]]
In a world this belligerent, what choice does she have but isolation?
*122242*
[[S:MIMIR:vo_glo_boatlore_OdnLore3_secbrk10_010_mmr_a:40-2380]]
Worse still, he robbed her of her warrior spirit.
*122243*
[[S:MIMIR:vo_glo_boatlore_OdnLore3_secbrk10_010_mmr_c:250-3970]]
No living thing may she harm, by blade nor spell.
*122244*
[[S:MIMIR:vo_glo_boatlore_OdnLore3_secbrk10_010_mmr_b:280-3320]]
Freya cannot fight—even to defend herself.
*122245*
[[S:SON:vo_glo_boatlore_OdnLore3_secbrk11_010_son:0-810]]
Poor Freya…
*122246*
[[S:::1840-2810]]
I guess if I was her,
*122247*
[[S:::3390-4586]]
I’d spit in your face too.
*122248*
[[S:MIMIR:vo_glo_boatlore_OdnLore3_secbrk12_010_mmr:60-850]]
Aye, lad.
*122249*
[[S:::1650-2250]]
So would I.
*122250*
[[S:SON:vo_glo_boatlore_TyrOdin_sec1_cus_res_010_son:0-550]]
So…
*122251*
[[S:::1010-3000]]
why was Týr helping Odin meet with the Giant Kings?
*122252*
[[S:SON:vo_glo_boatlore_TyrOdin_sec2_cus_res_010_son:44-2232]]
So what happened when Týr brought Odin to Jötunheim?
*122253*
[[S:SON:vo_glo_boatlore_TyrOdin_sec3_cus_res_010_son:60-2250]]
So what happened after Odin was cast out of Jötunheim?
*122254*
[[S:SON:vo_glo_boatlore_TyrOdin_secbrk00_010_son:0-500]]
Mimir…
*122255*
[[S:::1490-4500]]
why did you say Týr felt responsible for what Odin did to the Giants?
*122256*
[[S:MIMIR:vo_glo_boatlore_TyrOdin_secbrk01_010_mmr:400-3290]]
There was an incident, shortly after the forging of Mjölnir,
*122257*
[[S:::3650-7000]]
when Týr arranged a diplomatic meeting between Odin and the Giant Kings.
*122258*
[[S:MIMIR:vo_glo_boatlore_TyrOdin_secbrk02_010_mmr:170-3759]]
This was when the Long War was young, when victory was still a thing dreamed of,
*122259*
[[S:::3759-7000]]
and the Jötnar might have tipped the balance between Aesir and Vanir.
*122260*
[[S:MIMIR:vo_glo_boatlore_TyrOdin_secbrk03_010_mmr:0-3265]]
Odin had persuaded Týr that the hammer was merely a deterrent—
*122261*
[[S:::3391-5750]]
a means to broker peace from a position of strength.
*122262*
[[S:MIMIR:vo_glo_boatlore_TyrOdin_secbrk04_010_mmr:60-4000]]
Týr was hopeful to convince all parties they would prosper best through peace.
*122263*
[[S:MIMIR:vo_glo_boatlore_TyrOdin_secbrk05_010_mmr:0-2420]]
He knew the Giants were deeply concerned about the hammer,
*122264*
[[S:::2830-5340]]
a super-weapon in hands they did not trust.
*122265*
[[S:::5880-7220]]
But they trusted Týr.
*122266*
[[S:MIMIR:vo_glo_boatlore_TyrOdin_secbrk06_010_mmr:0-5130]]
Týr always believed the best in people—and taking Odin at his word in his desire for peace,
*122267*
[[S:::5520-7250]]
he brought the Raven King to Jötunheim.
*122268*
[[S:MIMIR:vo_glo_boatlore_TyrOdin_secbrk07_010_mmr:430-2250]]
From there, things unraveled quickly.
*122269*
[[S:MIMIR:vo_glo_boatlore_TyrOdin_secbrk08_010_mmr:0-4050]]
The Giants anticipated Odin’s trickery, and exposed his true agenda,
*122270*
[[S:::4170-6250]]
to spy and steal their secret wisdom.
*122271*
[[S:MIMIR:vo_glo_boatlore_TyrOdin_secbrk09_010_mmr:50-4410]]
With magics, they expelled Odin from their realm, and cursed him never to return.
*122272*
[[S:MIMIR:vo_glo_boatlore_TyrOdin_secbrk10_010_mmr:0-760]]
Frustrated,
*122273*
[[S:::1210-4000]]
Odin visited his fury upon the Giants of Midgard.
*122274*
[[S:MIMIR:vo_glo_boatlore_TyrOdin_secbrk11_010_mmr:220-3656]]
Thor unleashed Mjölnir’s might upon any Giant he could find.
*122275*
[[S:::3836-7250]]
None could stand against the tide of slaughter that followed.
*122276*
[[S:MIMIR:vo_glo_boatlore_TyrOdin_secbrk12_010_mmr:40-3540]]
And at last it seems, with Týr’s aid, they retreated.
*122277*
[[S:::3813-6732]]
The tower disappeared, no Giants could be found in Midgard,
*122278*
[[S:::7236-11152]]
and no man nor god has set foot in Jötunheim since.
*122279*
[[S:SON:vo_glo_boatlore_MagModLore_sec1_cus_res_010_son:60-2250]]
So what happened after Hrungnir fell down on Thor?
*122280*
[[S:SON:vo_glo_boatlore_MagModLore_sec2_cus_res_010_son:0-2620]]
So what happened after Magni and Modi got Hrungnir off Thor?
*122281*
[[S:SON:vo_glo_boatlore_MagModLore_secbrk00_010_son:49-3867]]
Mimir… you never told us what Magni and Modi had to do with Hrungnir.
*122282*
[[S:MIMIR:vo_glo_boatlore_MagModLore_secbrk01_010_mmr:540-1180]]
Oh, yes.
*122283*
[[S:::1650-4790]]
Well, what happened after Hrungnir fell slain upon Thor,
*122284*
[[S:::5040-8450]]
was that nobody in the court could get the stone body off of him.
*122285*
[[S:MIMIR:vo_glo_boatlore_MagModLore_secbrk02_010_mmr:23-3838]]
Thor was no use at this point—his brain rattled, his breath shallow…
*122286*
[[S:::4267-7223]]
but none of Odin’s men were nearly strong enough to help.
*122287*
[[S:MIMIR:vo_glo_boatlore_MagModLore_secbrk03_010_mmr:0-3580]]
Then enter little Magni and Modi, no taller than shrubs,
*122288*
[[S:::4110-6316]]
and while nobody but myself was looking,
*122289*
[[S:::6658-9500]]
they flipped over Hrungnir’s corpse and freed their father.
*122290*
[[S:MIMIR:vo_glo_boatlore_MagModLore_secbrk04_010_mmr:80-3091]]
Magni, being blonder, got all the credit,
*122291*
[[S:::3373-6805]]
and Modi remained bitter about it, from that day to the end…
*122292*
[[S:::7145-8747]]
which, I don’t need to tell you about.
*122293*
[[S:MIMIR:vo_glo_boatlore_Goodfellow_sec1_cus_res_010_mmr:40-2490]]
Where were we then? Oh yes—my career!
*122294*
[[S:MIMIR:vo_glo_boatlore_Goodfellow_sec2_cus_res_010_mmr:80-940]]
Where were we then?
*122295*
[[S:::1380-2500]]
Oh yes—my first job!
*122296*
[[S:MIMIR:vo_glo_boatlore_Goodfellow_sec3_cus_res_010_mmr:90-4750]]
Let’s see… my first job! Right! Me n’ m’mates, in the employ of a faerie king.
*122297*
[[S:MIMIR:vo_glo_boatlore_Goodfellow_sec4_cus_res_010_mmr:0-1690]]
Let’s see… my first job! Right!
*122298*
[[S:::2230-6000]]
Me n’ m’mates had the run of the forest, as long as we kept the faerie king amused.
*122299*
[[S:SON:vo_glo_boatlore_Goodfellow_secbrk00_010_son:0-520]]
Mimir,
*122300*
[[S:::1350-3140]]
why did you work for Odin if he’s so horrible?
*122301*
[[S:MIMIR:vo_glo_boatlore_Goodfellow_secbrk01_010_mmr:60-2038]]
It’s my career!
*122302*
[[S:::2400-7499]]
And if you mean to make your career as a counselor to kings, you can’t very well rule out petty maniacs—
*122303*
[[S:::7828-9500]]
available positions are scarce enough!
*122304*
[[S:MIMIR:vo_glo_boatlore_Goodfellow_secbrk02_010_mmr:30-2662]]
My first master was a cruel piece of work as well,
*122305*
[[S:::2781-5775]]
but I learned through him the enduring power of wit,
*122306*
[[S:::6010-8250]]
which served me well with kings and gods alike.
*122307*
[[S:MIMIR:vo_glo_boatlore_Goodfellow_secbrk03_010_mmr:28-5023]]
I couldn’t have been much older than you when I started—a faerie king’s errand boy, and unofficial jester.
*122308*
[[S:MIMIR:vo_glo_boatlore_Goodfellow_secbrk04_010_mmr:0-2310]]
By night, my mates and I had the run of the forest.
*122309*
[[S:MIMIR:vo_glo_boatlore_Goodfellow_secbrk05_010_mmr:16-3204]]
Goodfellows, they called us—knavish sprites to the last.
*122310*
[[S:MIMIR:vo_glo_boatlore_Goodfellow_secbrk06_010_mmr:260-4310]]
We’d get up to all manner of mischief, making fools of the local mortals—
*122311*
[[S:::4730-8500]]
but as long as our lord was kept amused, we were spared the consequences.
*122312*
[[S:MIMIR:vo_glo_boatlore_Goodfellow_secbrk07_010_mmr:2180-3640]]
Then one day, he was not amused,
*122313*
[[S:::4460-5960]]
and I saw fit to move on.
*122314*
[[S:MIMIR:vo_glo_boatlore_Goodfellow_secbrk08_010_mmr:0-4660]]
Thankfully the ages and roads travelled since then have turned me from that merry wanderer
*122315*
[[S:::5250-8020]]
into the paragon of virtue you see before you today.
*122316*
[[S:MIMIR:vo_glo_boatlore_MmrOnWell_sec1_cus_res_010_mmr:70-970]]
Where was I?
*122317*
[[S:::1570-3250]]
Coming north, making a new start…
*122318*
[[S:MIMIR:vo_glo_boatlore_MmrOnWell_sec2_cus_res_010_mmr:0-3750]]
Now I believe I was just acquainting Odin with my mystic well of knowledge…
*122319*
[[S:MIMIR:vo_glo_boatlore_MmrOnWell_sec3_cus_res_010_mmr:50-550]]
Aye…
*122320*
[[S:SON:vo_glo_boatlore_MmrOnWell_sec3_cus_res_010_son:0-1630]]
So Odin gouged out his own eye?
*122321*
[[S:::2540-3860]]
’Cause of mushrooms you gave him?
*122322*
[[S:SON:vo_glo_boatlore_MmrOnWell_secbrk00_010_son:0-650]]
Mimir,
*122323*
[[S:::1260-2669]]
how’d you come to be in these lands?
*122324*
[[S:MIMIR:vo_glo_boatlore_MmrOnWell_secbrk01_010_mmr:170-5750]]
Lad, there comes a time in every man’s life when he changes his name and heads north to make a new start.
*122325*
[[S:MIMIR:vo_glo_boatlore_MmrOnWell_secbrk02_010_mmr:0-4500]]
If you live long enough to do this many times over, you might end up as far north as this place.
*122326*
[[S:MIMIR:vo_glo_boatlore_MmrOnWell_secbrk03_010_mmr:20-3470]]
By the time I arrived, I already knew Odin by his reputation—
*122327*
[[S:::4010-8679]]
and so I set to demonstrate my worth by coming to him with something I knew he’d value—
*122328*
[[S:::9010-11023]]
a mystic well of knowledge.
*122329*
[[S:MIMIR:vo_glo_boatlore_MmrOnWell_secbrk04_010_mmr:0-5750]]
Or rather, I should say, a well of water laced with enough mystic mushrooms to make a god see visions.
*122330*
[[S:MIMIR:vo_glo_boatlore_MmrOnWell_secbrk05_010_mmr:410-2500]]
Oh, he was rightly impressed.
*122331*
[[S:MIMIR:vo_glo_boatlore_MmrOnWell_secbrk06_010_mmr:35-3685]]
Can’t say for sure what he saw that led him to try gouging out his own eyes,
*122332*
[[S:::4005-6358]]
but I managed to restrain him before he finished the job.
*122333*
[[S:MIMIR:vo_glo_boatlore_MmrOnWell_secbrk07_010_mmr:0-5791]]
Then I persuaded him it had been his sacrifice, made for an even higher form of sight to be bestowed,
*122334*
[[S:::6028-7541]]
blah-de-blah-de-blah-de-blah.
*122335*
[[S:MIMIR:vo_glo_boatlore_MmrOnWell_secbrk08_010_mmr:20-1490]]
I used to think he never caught on.
*122336*
[[S:::2110-5750]]
But the day he took my eye, I realized he had never been fooled.
*122337*
[[S:MIMIR:vo_glo_boatlore_MmrOnWell_secbrk09_010_mmr:20-1418]]
He knew I’d outwitted him,
*122338*
[[S:::1767-5561]]
called the lesson wisdom, and hired me, to make sure from then on I was on his side.
*122339*
[[S:::5938-8378]]
And for a long, long time, I truly was.
*122340*
[[S:::9230-11098]]
Doesn’t mean he didn’t hold a grudge.
*122341*
[[S:MIMIR:vo_glo_boatlore_Mmr_Odin_sec1_cus_res_010_mmr:0-2500]]
I believe we were discussing my youthful ambitions…
*122342*
[[S:MIMIR:vo_glo_boatlore_Mmr_Odin_sec2_cus_res_010_mmr:0-4000]]
I believe I was sayin’… The Aesir had power, but lacked for strategy…
*122343*
[[S:MIMIR:vo_glo_boatlore_Mmr_Odin_sec3_cus_res_010_mmr:80-750]]
Where was I then?
*122344*
[[S:SON:vo_glo_boatlore_Mmr_Odin_sec3_cus_res_020_son:0-2200]]
You’d become Odin’s most trusted advisor.
*122345*
[[S:MIMIR:vo_glo_boatlore_Mmr_Odin_sec3_cus_res_030_mmr:0-700]]
Aye…
*122346*
[[S:SON:vo_glo_boatlore_Mmr_Odin_sec4_cus_res_010_son:8-2052]]
So what did you do to get Odin so mad at you?
*122347*
[[S:SON:vo_glo_boatlore_Mmr_Odin_sec5_cus_res_010_son:42-2965]]
Mimir—you were getting to how Odin turned on you.
*122348*
[[S:MIMIR:vo_glo_boatlore_Mmr_Odin_sec5_cus_res_020_mmr:0-2000]]
Well, I felt my duty to Odin had evolved…
*122349*
[[S:MIMIR:vo_glo_boatlore_Mmr_Odin_sec5_cus_res_020_mmr_a:260-2500]]
Well, I felt my duty to Odin had evolved…
*122350*
[[S:MIMIR:vo_glo_boatlore_Mmr_Odin_sec6_cus_res_010_mmr:0-1030]]
To finish what I was saying—
*122351*
[[S:::1500-5750]]
I tried to serve Odin by serving peace, and he took it as disloyalty.
*122352*
[[S:SON:vo_glo_boatlore_Mmr_Odin_secbrk00_010_son:70-733]]
Mimir,
*122353*
[[S:::1100-3600]]
I still don’t get why you ever wanted to work for Odin.
*122354*
[[S:MIMIR:vo_glo_boatlore_Mmr_Odin_secbrk01_010_mmr:20-2250]]
Back then, I was young enough to still be ambitious.
*122355*
[[S:MIMIR:vo_glo_boatlore_Mmr_Odin_secbrk02_010_mmr:30-3161]]
The Aesir gods were as powerful a force as I’d come across,
*122356*
[[S:::3420-7123]]
but they clearly lacked for strategy, focus, and sage counsel.
*122357*
[[S:MIMIR:vo_glo_boatlore_Mmr_Odin_secbrk03_010_mmr:0-2000]]
All this could I faithfully provide.
*122358*
[[S:MIMIR:vo_glo_boatlore_Mmr_Odin_secbrk04_010_mmr:60-4267]]
And so, a stranger from a far-off island found himself with Odin’s ear,
*122359*
[[S:::4667-7000]]
trusted as he trusted no one but himself.
*122360*
[[S:MIMIR:vo_glo_boatlore_Mmr_Odin_secbrk05_010_mmr:40-2640]]
And with that kind of power, laddie, I must confess—
*122361*
[[S:::3010-3750]]
there are perks.
*122362*
[[S:SON:vo_glo_boatlore_Mmr_Odin_secbrk06_010_son:0-1792]]
Yeah, but he’s Odin!
*122363*
[[S:MIMIR:vo_glo_boatlore_Mmr_Odin_secbrk07_010_mmr:30-2510]]
I never claimed to be perfect, laddie, only clever.
*122364*
[[S:::3300-4750]]
And often too clever by half.
*122365*
[[S:SON:vo_glo_boatlore_Mmr_Odin_secbrk08_010_son:26-1993]]
So what did you to do get Odin so mad at you?
*122366*
[[S:MIMIR:vo_glo_boatlore_Mmr_Odin_secbrk09_010_mmr:60-560]]
Well,
*122367*
[[S:::940-5290]]
for a long time, my job was to enable Odin, and I was fucking excellent at it.
*122368*
[[S:MIMIR:vo_glo_boatlore_Mmr_Odin_secbrk10_010_mmr:0-3390]]
Gradually, as I grew more to care about… people, and the world,
*122369*
[[S:::3960-5500]]
my job became to contain him.
*122370*
[[S:MIMIR:vo_glo_boatlore_Mmr_Odin_secbrk11_010_mmr:50-1500]]
To protect him from himself.
*122371*
[[S:MIMIR:vo_glo_boatlore_Mmr_Odin_secbrk12_010_mmr:0-3400]]
By serving peace, I served his interests as well, that’s the truth…
*122372*
[[S:::4020-5500]]
but he saw it as disloyalty.
*122373*
[[S:MIMIR:vo_glo_boatlore_Mmr_Odin_secbrk13_010_mmr:0-3890]]
No longer trusting my motives, but not wishing to part with my brain or tongue,
*122374*
[[S:::4400-8900]]
he bound me to a tree and adopted a new pastime of casual torture.
*122375*
[[S:SON:vo_glo_boatlore_Mmr_Odin_secbrk14_010_son:25-2692]]
Well, I’m glad we came along to cut off your head.
*122376*
[[S:MIMIR:vo_glo_boatlore_Mmr_Odin_secbrk15_010_mmr:50-960]]
Aye, lad.
*122377*
[[S:::1360-2410]]
Lucky break that was.
*122378*
[[S:MIMIR:vo_glo_boatlore_Hrimthur_sec1_cus_res_010_mmr:60-4930]]
What were we into, then? Oh! The revenge plot of Hrimthur, the stone mason’s son.
*122379*
[[S:MIMIR:vo_glo_boatlore_Hrimthur_sec2_cus_res_010_mmr:130-960]]
We were at…
*122380*
[[S:::1380-5750]]
the stone mason’s son, plotting revenge, observed the shoddiness of Asgard’s walls.
*122381*
[[S:MIMIR:vo_glo_boatlore_Hrimthur_sec3_cus_res_010_mmr:190-5000]]
So then! Hrimthur, the stone mason’s son in disguise, offered to fix Asgard’s walls.
*122382*
[[S:MIMIR:vo_glo_boatlore_Hrimthur_sec4_cus_res_010_mmr:280-5750]]
Alright, the stone mason’s son, Hrimthur—he builds Asgard a great wall, and demands his prize.
*122383*
[[S:SON:vo_glo_boatlore_Hrimthur_sec5_cus_res_010_son:40-2780]]
So… Hrimthur just wanted to whisper in Freya’s ear?
*122384*
[[S:MIMIR:vo_glo_boatlore_Hrimthur_sec5_cus_res_020_mmr:30-1000]]
Aye…
*122385*
[[S:MIMIR:vo_glo_boatlore_Hrimthur_sec6_cus_res_010_mmr:80-4800]]
We’d come to the part where Thor caught up with Hrimthur, and slew the stone mason’s son.
*122386*
[[S:SON:vo_glo_boatlore_Hrimthur_sec7_cus_res_020_son:30-2250]]
So what did the stone mason’s son whisper to Freya?
*122387*
[[S:SON:vo_glo_boatlore_Hrimthur_secbrk00_010_son:30-3420]]
Mimir, you never told me what happened with the stonemason’s son.
*122388*
[[S:::4240-5430]]
You said he’d have his revenge.
*122389*
[[S:MIMIR:vo_glo_boatlore_Hrimthur_secbrk01_010_mmr_b:79-3246]]
I said he’d plot his revenge, and so he did.
*122390*
[[S:SON:vo_glo_boatlore_Hrimthur_secbrk00_010_son_b:50-1250]]
You said he’d have his revenge.
*122391*
[[S:MIMIR:vo_glo_boatlore_Hrimthur_secbrk01_010_mmr:20-1510]]
Hrimthur, son of Thamur?
*122392*
[[S:::1900-4950]]
I said he’d plot his revenge, and so he did.
*122393*
[[S:SON:vo_glo_boatlore_Hrimthur_secbrk00_010_son_a:0-491]]
Mimir,
*122394*
[[S:::960-3000]]
you never told me what happened with the stonemason’s son.
*122395*
[[S:MIMIR:vo_glo_boatlore_Hrimthur_secbrk01_010_mmr_a:30-1500]]
Hrimthur, son of Thamur?
*122396*
[[S:MIMIR:vo_glo_boatlore_Hrimthur_secbrk02_010_mmr:50-3968]]
After completing his father’s masterwork, the Great Wall of Jötunheim,
*122397*
[[S:::4240-8617]]
he thought of nothing but making the Aesir pay for their crimes against the Giants.
*122398*
[[S:MIMIR:vo_glo_boatlore_Hrimthur_secbrk03_010_mmr:0-4360]]
Once he longed to fight Thor, but tragedy had brought wisdom to Hrimthur—
*122399*
[[S:::4720-5750]]
and cunning.
*122400*
[[S:MIMIR:vo_glo_boatlore_Hrimthur_secbrk04_010_mmr:300-4276]]
He observed that Asgard’s walls were half-built and shoddy,
*122401*
[[S:::4464-7500]]
for no Aesir god could be bothered with such tiresome labor.
*122402*
[[S:MIMIR:vo_glo_boatlore_Hrimthur_secbrk05_010_mmr:0-4540]]
So Hrimthur adopted the guise of an ordinary man, and made the Aesir an offer—
*122403*
[[S:::5080-7300]]
he would build them majestic new walls,
*122404*
[[S:::7300-9360]]
and if he couldn’t build them within two turns of the season,
*122405*
[[S:::9360-11200]]
they would owe him nothing for his labors.
*122406*
[[S:MIMIR:vo_glo_boatlore_Hrimthur_secbrk06_010_mmr:30-1130]]
And if he succeeded,
*122407*
[[S:::1690-4656]]
he asked only for an audience with the goddess Freya.
*122408*
[[S:MIMIR:vo_glo_boatlore_Hrimthur_secbrk07_010_mmr:180-4750]]
Odin agreed, knowing the task was impossible, but intrigued by this stranger.
*122409*
[[S:MIMIR:vo_glo_boatlore_Hrimthur_secbrk08_010_mmr:0-4120]]
Hrimthur made short work of it, of course—he had the benefit of his father’s training,
*122410*
[[S:::4120-6500]]
and the aid of a magical stallion for fetching stones.
*122411*
[[S:MIMIR:vo_glo_boatlore_Hrimthur_secbrk09_010_mmr:100-3739]]
Odin was not happy to find himself on the losing end of the wager,
*122412*
[[S:::4057-6420]]
but he seemed to uphold his end of the bargain.
*122413*
[[S:MIMIR:vo_glo_boatlore_Hrimthur_secbrk10_010_mmr:0-1530]]
Freya was sent to meet the mason,
*122414*
[[S:::2030-5000]]
and to her surprise, he wanted only to whisper something in her ear.
*122415*
[[S:MIMIR:vo_glo_boatlore_Hrimthur_secbrk11_010_mmr:120-3010]]
That being done, he made his way out of Asgard…
*122416*
[[S:::3870-8314]]
and when he found Thor awaiting him at the gates of Midgard, he knew he had been double-crossed.
*122417*
[[S:MIMIR:vo_glo_boatlore_Hrimthur_secbrk12_010_mmr:22-4557]]
But he didn’t care, because his plan was complete.
*122418*
[[S:SON:vo_glo_boatlore_Hrimthur_secbrk13_010_son:60-760]]
It was?
*122419*
[[S:::1630-2607]]
What did he say to Freya?
*122420*
[[S:MIMIR:vo_glo_boatlore_Hrimthur_secbrk14_010_mmr:0-3500]]
Only she could say for certain, but I’ve had many moons to work it out.
*122421*
[[S:MIMIR:vo_glo_boatlore_Hrimthur_secbrk15_010_mmr:440-4340]]
Hrimthur knew that Freya loathed the Aesir, despite her marriage to Odin,
*122422*
[[S:::4730-7500]]
and I believe he gave her the secret to Asgard’s defenses.
*122423*
[[S:MIMIR:vo_glo_boatlore_Hrimthur_secbrk16_010_mmr:20-3589]]
Some weakness he may have built in, structural or magical,
*122424*
[[S:::3816-9800]]
which I expect will be exploited come Ragnarök when Surtr arrives to burn Asgard to ash.
*122425*
[[S:::10180-11130]]
If not sooner.
*122426*
[[S:SON:vo_glo_boatlore_TriptychsToGo_010_son:0-1350]]
Got any more Giant stories, Mimir?
*122427*
[[S:MIMIR:vo_glo_boatlore_TriptychsToGo_020_mmr:50-2500]]
Well, if you see any more shrines about, you can always ask.
*122428*
[[S:SON:vo_glo_boatlore_WrapOnMimir_010_son:37-1883]]
Don’t you have any more stories to tell, Mimir?
*122429*
[[S:MIMIR:vo_glo_boatlore_WrapOnMimir_020_mmr:50-1070]]
I’m talked out, lad.
*122430*
[[S:::1740-4250]]
But some day I imagine I’ll be telling your story.
*122431*
[[S::vo_lvl_pro03_s620_010_son_stem:2945-3609]]
What was that—?
*122432*
[[S::vo_lvl_pro03_s620_010_kra_stem:3820-4553]]
Your bow..!
*122433*
[[S:::26794-28327]]
Who are you?!
*122434*
[[S:SON:vo_lvl_pro03_s010_010_son:32-4038]]

*122435*
[[S:MIMIR:vo_lvl_pro03_s010_020_mmr:27-4161]]

*122436*
[[S:SON:vo_lvl_pro03_s030_010_son:30-4910]]

*122437*
[[S:KRATOS:vo_lvl_pro03_s030_010_kra:20-1000]]

*122438*
[[S:SON:vo_lvl_pro03_s030_020_son:10-1311]]

*122439*
[[S:MIMIR:vo_lvl_pro03_s030_030_mmr:60-2080]]

*122440*
[[S:SON:vo_lvl_pro03_s030_040_son:31-935]]

*122441*
[[S:SON:vo_lvl_pro03_s030_050_son:0-500]]

[[S:SON:vo_lvl_pro03_s040_020_son:540-1670]]

[[S:KRATOS:vo_lvl_pro03_s050_010_kra:0-1750]]

*122448*

*122455*

[[S:KRATOS:vo_lvl_pro03_s050_050_kra:0-2179]]
